title: London 2012 organiser: Toyko Games 'unlikely' to take place
content:
Will Strickson
20 Jan 2021

Deputy chairman of the London Organising Committee Sir Keith Mills told 5 Live: 'I would be making plans for a cancellation'

Deputy chairman of the London Organising Committee Sir Keith Mills has said that 'it looks unlikely' that the rescheduled Tokyo Olympics will go ahead.

Speaking on BBC Radio 5 Live's Wake Up to Money programme yesterday morning, Mills, who is the chairman of the Invictus Games, said: 'If I were sitting in the shoes of the organising committee in Tokyo, I would be making plans for a cancellation.'

With Covid-19 cases and deaths across the world reaching record highs and a state of emergency declared in Toyko and its surrounding areas, the prospect of safely bringing in athletes and their entourages from all corners of the globe is daunting even with vaccines being rolled out.

However, Mills believes the problems don't end with simply getting the games on: 'The Olympic Games is all about identifying the best athletes in the world across a whole range of different sports. If the best athletes in the world can't get there it starts to invalidate the legitimacy of the medals that are being dished out.'

Although sporting events have been pulled off successfully since the pandemic began, the size of the Olympics makes it a bigger risk and measures like the NBA's Disneyland bubble, tennis players' quarantining in hotel rooms prior to the upcoming Australian Open and the rigorous testing to get all three Grand Tours on, would be incredibly difficult with the number of people involved.

To add to that, the suggestion by International Olympic Committee member Dick Pound to give athletes priority access to the vaccine presents a moral dilemma if those most at risk have not yet had it.
